div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchant William Dawkins, August 3, 1717, commenting on politics in England and disparaging the Tories.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to William Dawkins, August 3, 1717
div1.p:
x x x x x
x x x x
Pray God bless King George &
send him to crush all his enemies at
home & abroad If the Tories will
set up for a King of their own and make
him above the controul of Law, pro=
vided they will withdraw to a country
where they & their King may quietly
enjoy their mutual claims upon
one another according to their hearts
content— he his despotic, unreason=
able sovereighty— they their passive,
brutish subjection, lett but us & our
legal King alone, I'll never envy
them. Att the same time, whig=
gism, I must tell you under the
rose, hath no abundance of patrons
among us. You know by this time
what means the mightly change lately
made in this Ministry. Such ruptures
have too often bad consequences.
But I leave politics & conclude for the present.
Sir

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Minor-Blackford Papers, James Monroe Law Office and Museum, Fredericksburg, Virginia. These texts are all nineteenth-century copies. Apparently there was in existence a letter book of Robert Carter's—now lost—from which the unknown copiest recorded these texts. As they are the only texts, the punctuation and "corrections" obviously supplied by the copiest have been retained. The copist used rows of the letter "x" to indicate material that he did not copy from the letter book.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The return address, county, and state have been added for clarity on this unheaded letter.
[1] George I, who reigned from 1714 to 1727, the first Hanoverian.

[2] Carter refers to the struggle between the Whigs and the Tories which brought the Whigs to power in 1715, and resulted in a contest between factions of the Whigs for supremacy. Sir Robert Walpole and Viscount Townshend led one faction, and the earls of Stanhope and Sunderland led the other.
[3] James, first Earl Stanhope, replaced Charles , second Viscount Townshend, as leading minister in 1717; both were Whigs.
